head.title: Evolution in Europe; Britain Blocks European Move on Pollution

hedline.hl1: Evolution in Europe; Britain Blocks European Move on Pollution

body.head.byline: Special to The New York Times

block.p: LEAD: Britain and three other countries blocked moves by the European Community today to set the year 2000 as a deadline for stabilizing carbon-dioxide emissions, which are thought to be contributing to the earth's warming.

LEAD: Britain and three other countries blocked moves by the European Community today to set the year 2000 as a deadline for stabilizing carbon-dioxide emissions, which are thought to be contributing to the earth's warming.

Britain and three other countries blocked moves by the European Community today to set the year 2000 as a deadline for stabilizing carbon-dioxide emissions, which are thought to be contributing to the earth's warming.

At a meeting of environmental officials from the 12-nation community, Britain said it could not improve its commitment to stabilize the emissions at 1990 levels by the year 2005, a position made public by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher last month. The meeting was held in Luxembourg.

The community's Environment Commissioner, Carlo Ripa di Meana, urged adoption of the year 2000 target date, reportedly hoping that this would bring pressure on the United States to follow suit. The United States is responsible for about one-quarter of world carbon-dioxide output.

In resisting this deadline, Britain was backed by Spain, Portugal and Greece, three of the poorest countries in the community. Diplomats said Spain suggested limiting carbon dioxide emissions on a per-capita basis, which would require more industrialized countries to adopt stiffer controls.

Mr. Ripa di Meana said he was hopeful that environment officials in the community would reach agreement on an early deadline when they next meet in October. ''I don't think 2005 is Mrs. Thatcher's last word,'' he said.

At the same meeting, the European Community agreed on Thursday to continue campaigning for a ban on chemicals that destroy the ozone, to come into force between 1997 and 2000. They also pledged to help third world countries switch from chlorofluorocarbons and halons to chemicals thought less harmful to the environment.
